item.description:
In Dungeon Rush, players are adventurers rushing through a perilous dungeon to root out evil, earning coins and improving their abilities along the way. After three levels (with three rounds of monsters in each level) they face the Dungeon Lord and the Dragon.

Each player has two heroes, one for their right hand and one for their left. Players simultaneously reveal two dungeon cards each and quickly put their hands on the cards they want their heroes to fight. If you win, you claim the card as loot or equipment that increases the abilities of your hero. Equipment cards are placed partly under your hero card, with the ability symbol sticking out. This way the four different types of abilities — Melee, Ranged, Magic and Stealth — are built up in one direction each, out from your hero.

For particularly strong monsters, your heroes can combine their power by hitting the monster with both your hands.

item.description:
The armies from hell are upon England! Only one man can stop this demonic force: Sherlock Holmes, consulting detective.

London After Midnight 2: Sherlock in Hell is a fun, fast and crazy card game for the whole family that can be played both as an standalone game and as an expansion for "London After Midnight".

•••

Las fuerzas del infierno amenazan Inglaterra y sólo un hombre puede detenerlas antes de que sea tarde: Sherlock Holmes, detective consultor.
 London after midnight 2: Sherlock in hell es un juego de cartas rápido, loco y endiabladamente divertido. Puede jugarse de forma independiente o como expansión de London after midnight.

item.description:
This undated game combines die rolling with memory. Each player takes a bingo-like card with four numbered columns and seven rows of circles and covers each circle with a plastic disk (plack). On each card, 12 circles are blank, and the remainder have instructions such as "Pick-A-Plack"; "Others cover one blank", "Have another turn" or "Cover two blanks".

Players take turns rolling a die. On a 1-4, they may remove one plack from that column; on a 5, they must replace a plack on an open location of their choice; and on a 6, they may remove a plack from any one location. When removing a plack, they obey whatever instructions are underneath. The player who first removes all the placks on his card wins.

Despite the random element of die rolling, the key to victory is using required replacement of placks to re-cover useful spots, and remembering which of these will be most useful in each future situation.

It’s thought that all bees work for the good of the colony. However the Queen is allowed to have one favourite; a worker who is smarter and collects more nectar than the rest. That bee is called, THE NIMBEE.

GAME OBJECTIVE
In Nimbee, you must direct your honey bee around the hive to collect honey and other benefits to best prepare for the excursion into the meadow. There you must search for the sweetest nectar-laden flowers; settle on the bonuses first, or fly ahead to stop your opponents getting to the best blooms. Will you get the timing right and claim the ultimate prize in the secluded glade at the end of the path, or will you fall foul of the greedy bear who wants to raid your hive? At the end of the game the player who has collected the most nectar will be awarded the title of NIMBEE.

item.description:
This is one of the seven "Grandma's" games issued by Milton Bradley in the early 1900s. This one, as the title suggests, is a geographical quiz. It consists of 119 plain cards each with a single numbered question, and a booklet with directions and all the answers.

Players are given at least six cards each, and take turns flipping over a single one of their cards. If that player cannot answer the question, he passes it to his left, and each player in turn has the opportunity to answer. Whichever player answers correctly keeps the card, and the player with the most cards wins.

While the box is undated, Alex G. Malloy dates it to 1910 (American Games, 1999, p. 35, #1081), and the questions confirm the period: Cuba is shown as an independent nation, while the largest Empire in the world is still Russia, with its capital at Petrograd. Interestingly for an American game, 11 of the questions (almost 1/10) deal with what is now Canada.

This undated Chad Valley title is a dexterity game using a wood and metal spring launcher, a hollow celluloid ball, and five target birds, also hollow celluloid, that balance on a wire.

The box is used as the base for the target. A cardboard cutout of a row of trees, ranging from 6" to 8" high, is inserted into two wooden holders fixed at the front of the box. Two 10" wooden poles are inserted in two other wooden blocks fixed to the box near the back, and have a string running between them. The birds are balanced on the string, and players must shoot over the trees to hit the birds. Any number of rounds may be played, with the player having the biggest bag winning.

The instructions inside the box lid show that three other versions of the game were produced: the smallest with just a cardboard backdrop, a larger square version with four poles and strings, and a huge octagonal version with eight poles in two squares at different heights, shown with 21 birds perches and more fallen.

Autodrop is fun game named after famous Dutch candy. It's a simple but fun game where all players race their way to the finish with real candy. Up to four players choose 5 candies they will use as their pawns and with a dice they move forward on the game board. On the way players eat, switch, jump and fight to master the first place so they can eventually finish first! Can you win this race frenzy?!

item.description:
This 1966 game is based on the Apollo project aimed at putting the first man on the moon. It is a game for 2-6 players, who roll dice to move around the board while building up a full four-stage Saturn rocket and then successfully launching it.

Components include the board, 36 Astronaut (or "Condition") playing cards with period photographs, 20 yellow Chance cards, 8 green Espionage cards, 12 pink Sabotage cards, 4 plastic rockets, each in four stages, 6 wooden rocket playing pieces, money in "mios" or $millions, and 36 markers.

To do so, players must land on squares allowing them to collect research grants, buy rocket parts or "Condition" cards that fill in each player's Control Board, and collect Chance, Espionage or Sabotage cards to help their own projects or hurt their opponents. There is even a funny "Astronaut Training" space where players must get up and do 10 knee bends or pay 100 mio for being out of condition. Players may trade cards or parts by moving into another player's home area.

Once all four stages are ready and the Control Board is full, a player may attempt a final Count Down. He must roll 2D6 three times, and if he gets a cumulative total of 25 or more, he wins the game. He may roll again on succeeding turns unless of course his project is sabotaged.

Grab some peanuts and Cracker Jack and pull up a seat to The Old Ball Game!

TOBG is a head-2-head, traditional base ball game, featuring real-time pitching (no charts or die rolls to determine results). Players can enjoy a full 9 innings or set a score and play only the 9th.

The emphasis in on the heart of the game - pitching, with timely hitting sprinkled in and solid fielding (except for the occasional error!)

TOBG moves along smoothly and quickly, with the time of play dictated by the time to pitch. Meaning you can take your time or play fast - it's up to you. There are special rules for stealing and bunting; and old-fashioned score boards keep track of the count and score, for that Authentic feel.

Pitching: The pitcher has 7 pitches to choose from. The pitching happens in 2 stages with the batter saying 'Take' or 'Swing' at each pitch. The result is a ball or strike. As the count goes deeper, the batter gets the advantage and knowledge will prevail over luck.

Hitting: When the batter swings at a Strike he gets a potential hit - he flips over a batting card to reveal a single, double, triple (or home-run!), hit to various areas of the ball park. (There are also infield flies.)

Fielding: The fielding team will select which fielding card to turn over to make the play. Results are Out, Hit or Error.

Introducing an exclusive collection of pieces created to commemorate the 112 years at the Boleyn Ground.
In summer 2016, West Ham United will say goodbye tothe venerable Boleyn Ground, home of the club for over a century.
Situated in Newham Borough's heart in East London, The Boleyn Ground was opened in 1904, when the Hammers were still a Southern League club.
In 1919, the stadium hosted its first Football League match and became a successful Premier League team when the competition arrived in 1993.
Special Edition "Farewell Boleyn" Monopoly.
Gives you the chance to invest in stands and stadiums and trade in landmarks and players!

Buurman & Buurman Cardhouse Game is a game where players try to build a house out of cards. Each team (existing of any number of players) starts with a floor and places two "wall cards" on it. After that, both teams try to place more floors and more walls to obtain points and create the biggest card-house. When one of the teams houses falls, the other team wins, or when both players finish their house by placing the roof, the teams count the points they obtained.

item.description:
Game description from the designer:

This is a new semi-cooperative card game of political negotiation, deception and voting in which players are politicians from the two big parties but who also try to push forward an individual hidden agenda. This game was initially designed as a game-base learning tool at the London School of Economics and Political Science to introduce students to collective decision-making, game theory and market regulation. The game scales well at different player counts and plays under 1 hour. Gamers and non-gamers alike will enjoy Kill the Bill. It rewards experienced players who manage well their hand of cards and use them in the appropriate way and at the right time. However, the game can be also thoroughly enjoyed as a party game with a strong take-that component in which negotiation and bluffing skills may compensate the lack of experience playing the tactics cards.

Overview
In Kill the Bill, players are members of a high profile Committee in the U.S. Congress who try to pass legislation benefiting both their political party and their own secret individual agenda. Each year 3 bills are discussed and voted by the Committee. The goal of the game is to become the most popular politician by the end of the fourth year (round) so to become the front-runner in the next presidential campaign. 
Players obtain points by passing bills which are favorable to the interest of their party (party scoring track), or favorable to their individual agenda (agenda scoring track). Moreover players get (and lose) popularity points throughout the game as effect of the political tactics cards played. Skillful persuasion and negotiation are important to success. However, in politics things are never straightforward. A wide range of political tactics (cards) are available to players who can unexpectedly turn decisive votes in their favor. Building alliances across the party lines, having a long-term strategy in mind and showing tactical flexibility are important in "Kill the Bill" too. Players must be ready for blackmail, bribery, deception and treason. Sometimes the end justifies the means.

Turn order
Each round consist of 4 phases:
1-Preparation (new tactics cards are dealt -draft in the first year, Committee Chair is selected and bills presented)
2-Logrolling (negotiation) phase: players try to persuade each other to support or oppose certain bills
3-Political tactics phase: tactics cards are played
4-Voting phase: bills are voted and scoring tracks adjusted.

item.description:
Build your own town in Design Town! In this deck-building game, you have no hand at all; instead, you play cards directly from the top of your deck. Winning the game requires delicate strategies...and some luck as well!!

A turn consists of two phases: card playing and building.

• Players play cards directly from the top of their deck and may choose to continue unless they have three cry-face icons in play, which ends their turn immediately. When they choose to stop, they move to the building phase.

• During the building phase, a player can use the coins gained from their previously played cards to buy a new card or to upgrade a card in their personal discard pile. To upgrade a card, pay the cost and flip it over; upgraded cards remain in the discard pile.

Since all cards in this game are double-sided, be careful not to flip them over accidentally when placing cards into your discard pile or when shuffling your deck. Whenever a player gains eight or more VP during a single card playing phase, that player wins immediately!

This edition of Design Town consists of the original Design Town from Homosapiens Lab as well as the Design Town: Reuse expansion that adds two more double-sided cards to the game.

item.description:
The cities of the future continue to expand…upward! As buildings get taller, skyways are constructed to connect buildings above street level to allow for easier foot traffic between them.

In Skyways, you and your opponents are building the city, floor by floor and skyway by skyway. By placing tiles of the same color, you can score large numbers of points. By placing a building capital on top, you finish a building and claim a colored area for yourself for bonus points at the end of the game. Do you want to score more now and risk giving your opponent a larger area connected to their capital, or do you want to get your capitals out as quickly as you can and enlarge your own areas for the end game?

The player with the most points when the tiles have been placed wins!

item.description:
Galleons overloaded with gold are the desired catch for sea wolfs. The most influential pirate lords have gathered at the port to put together a team of sailors to board the traders' fleet. Seizing the gold is just half of the business, however; it’s much harder to…share it.

In Pirate Lords, you gather masters of saber, steering wheel, and pistol under your flag — then passionately bargain with other players for the booty. Only in unity can pirates overpower a trader's defenses. Will you show greediness or generously share rewards? Your victory in the game depends on timely decisions.

item.description:
Each player is dealt 7 white cards, each including a word or phrase. Each round, players take turns serving as the judge, drawing one black card containing a question or fill in the blank sentence.

Players answer the question or fill in the blank sentence by choosing their favorite white card to fill it in. Each player takes turns judging, choosing their favorite option and the funniest answer wins the round.

link.value: Humanity Hates Hillary, Too: Expansion Two

item.description:
Love Will Tear Us Apart
A sad little game about dividing your stuff after a divorce.

How to play: 
 
1. Hold the paper up between each other for 5 seconds. The side you are looking at shows your goal items. You then flip the paper over so each player is looking at the other player's side. (maybe draw a little stick figure example?)
 
2. Each player takes turns trying to rip out a single item at a time from the items on their goal side WITHOUT looking at it while the other player holds the page up.
 
3. Each item successful ripped off in full, with no pieces of any other item on the same piece is worth one point. Most points when all the items are taken or damaged wins.
 
4. Check PrettiestPrincessGames.com for a rules video and more details and variants.

You'll find that in the process of trying to get the most stuff, you'll not only end up destroying what you want by accident, but also knowingly trashing the stuff your ex wants.

Part of the Prettiest Princess Games Consumable 1-Sheet line.

Roll it. Spark it. Score it. Do you have what it takes to get the HIGHEST score?

Rules:

1. Roll it. Roll this paper into your best interpretation of a jazz cigarette; score side on the inside.

2. Spark it. Light it on fire. Literally. Be safe. Or don't. Whatever.

3. Score it. You can put out the fire whenever you choose, however you choose. Score the burn line furthest from the start. HIGHEST score wins or play multiple rounds to 420.

Note: Don't be a moron and actually set yourself or your stuff on fire.

Part of the Prettiest Princess Games Consumable 1-Sheet line.

Hungarian Rhapsody depicts the Soviet drive into Hungary which led the Red Army into the Vienna basin. Rumania's defection in August 1944 allowed the Soviets to outflank well defended Axis positions in the Carpathian Mountains through the South. In the process, the German 6th Army was almost destroyed, losing most of its heavy equipment (which explains the relative weakness of the German artillery at the start of the campaign). The game begins on 5 October 1944 with the 2nd Ukrainian Front and the 4th Ukrainian Front launching an offensive to isolate the German 8th Army which is still defending an area off-map to the East in the Carpathian Mountains.

Hungarian Rhapsody allows players to play the two major Soviet offensives and several smaller scenarios covering the German counter offensives.

Hungarian Rhapsody is the next game in the award winning Operational Combat System. Players control units ranging from battalions through divisions, making key decisions on the use, objectives, and means of war. The series is based on modern concepts of maneuver warfare and allows players a far more insightful look into how campaigns (large and small) really work.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: Half Week
Hex: 5 miles / 8 Km
Units: Battalion to Division

A game of trivia, teamwork, & campaign strategy. Ages 10 and up, for 2-8 players.
ELECTION! The Presidential Campaign Game
2nd Edition
Overview:
Citizens vote to elect our president. In this game, you can lead the campaign! ELECTION! is a game of trivia, teamwork, & campaign strategy. Players compete to be the first party to claim the most electoral votes in an American Presidential election campaign. Players lead their party’s campaign for president by raising funds and purchasing Town Hall, Advertise, and Charisma cards to earn votes. Then with votes in hand, they strategically claim State's electoral votes and ensure their party's victory. Game Play:

Each turn involves three actions.
1 Roll dice
2 Buy Cards
3 Claim States
ACTION 1: Players can choose to roll the dice to raise funds. ACTION 2: They can opt to buy cards to build their campaign and earn popular votes. For example, buy a Town Hall trivia card to test your knowledge of history, State Capitals, State nicknames, and more. A correct response earns the votes. ACTION 3: With popular votes in hand, the players use them to win selected States on the score ballot.

Players may also "endorse" a teammate after their three actions. This is done by forwarding cards to a teammate's hand, pooling cards and votes to claim more States during their turn. Can the party now claim enough electoral votes to win the election?

Game progress is kept on the score ballot. The score ballot lists all 50 states and DC, and is sorted based on presidential election results from 1988 through 2008. There are states that lean red, states that lean blue, and swing states in the middle. States that lean toward the player's political party require fewer popular votes to claim. The swing states are equal for each party, and are more difficult for both. By claiming states with earned votes, players win electoral votes for their party and work toward victory. The electoral votes listed are current for the 2012, 2016, and 2020 presidential elections.

Exiles is a fast-paced, frenetic, buzzword-filled game of gritty Wild West adventure. The game plays as a "miniatures role-playing game" because it runs like an RPG and plays like a skirmish wargame. One player acts as the game master, or governor, and the others play against a scenario of his or her creation. The game ends when the players win or lose depending on the scenario's conditions or if the players survive.

name.value: Marvel Universe Miniature Game: The Dark Avengers Starter Set

item.description:
This game is a small scale skirmish level game where Superheroes and Villains face off against each other in a 3D tabletop set up. It could be a city, the Wakandan desert, the Savage Lands, the blue area of the moon or anything you like. In Marvel they fight anywhere.
It is played on a 36" x 36" board so will fit on most tables without a problem.

In a game you will usually have between 4-7 characters on your team. Each of these characters act individually using their own Power to carry out different attacks and use Special Powers.
Many can help or hinder each others though with boosts and actions like a Fastball Special.

The aim of the game is to win set scenarios by completing different tasks and scoring Victory Points. These could be anything from take down / save the highest Level model in the team or rescue and keep a Cosmic Relic.

Each character comes with their own Stat Card which shows everything they can do. Attacks, Defence, Skills, Power, Damage and such.
These are then used in a 2 D8 mechanic during the game. For example, 2D8 plus Attack Stat vs Defence Stat or 2D8 against your own Agility.

Reformed supervillain Norman Osborn, now calling himself the Iron Patriot, was given leadership of the espionage agency S.H.I.E.L.D. He reformed that agency into H.A.M.M.E.R. and created a new Avengers team under its aegis. The line-up consists of former Thunderbolts members and new recruits Sentry and Ares, as well as disguised super-villain Moonstone who is portraying Ms. Marvel. Using the Dark Avengers as a cover Norman declared war on the Asgardians, and has the Dark Avengers prepare for the Siege of Asgard. Norman considered The Sentry, specifically his dark side, known as The Void, his secret weapon.

link.value: DC Universe Miniature Game: Batman V Superman Trinity Starter Set
Marvel Universe Miniature Game: Brotherhood of Evil Mutants Starter Set
Marvel Universe Miniature Game: Guardians of the Galaxy Starter Set
Marvel Universe Miniature Game: The Avengers Starter Set
Marvel Universe Miniature Game: X-Men Starter Set

item.description:
Game description from the designer:

Figment is a cooperative, narrative card game for children ages 6 and up. Players are required to work closely together and use each other's individual strengths to defeat classic opponents from medieval fantasy tales and, as a team, prevent the destruction of the mythic kingdom!

Each player chooses one of ten classic and recognizable characters: a knight, a barbarian, an elf, a wizard, a princess, and so on. Each character has a specific combination of skills, represented by colorful icons, that can be used to defeat monsters along the way; stars represent physical might, while books stand for lore and hearts embody social skills. As the right combination of skill icons is required to defeat monsters and eventually dethrone the main villain of the piece. By doing this, children not only see that they differ from the other players, they even need to make good use of the other players' strengths — and help them cope with their weaknesses — to succeed.

Players start off in the idyllic medieval kingdom, where they'll confront weaker monsters drawn randomly from a stack of encounters while also traveling from one location to the next. When they feel up to it, certain locations give them access to the evil Shadowrealm, where stronger monsters roam but ancient, powerful magics can also be discovered. In this realm of darkness and shadow, they eventually have to defeat the one, powerful creature who has been organizing the monsters for an all-out assault on the kingdom...

Figment is ideal for young children and was developed in cooperation with educators and elementary school teachers.

item.description:
This 1890 game from Milton Bradley uses the Happy Families/Authors mechanism of building sets by asking for cards, but complicates strategy through a set of bonus cards.

The game consists of 95 small card slips, roughly 2.5" long by 0.5" wide. Of these, 18 contain the name of a Longfellow poem, 72 have the name of the poem and two lines from it, and five contain the names of styles of edition bindings: Tree Calf; Full Morocco; Half Morocco; Cloth; and Paper. There also are six larger reference slips with the names of all 18 poems.

Players take turns asking for a poem or selections from a poem, and when they complete a set, play it down in front of them. They also may ask for an "edition slip", and if the asked player has one, he must hand it over. If he has more than one, he chooses which to hand over.

All but the Paper slip provide a bonus that applies to all sets scored at the time it is played. Bonuses are cumulative, so a doubled pair plus two more sets then tripled equals 18 points. However, whichever player is left with the Paper slip at the end of the game cuts his total score in half. Highest net score wins.

The game is listed by Alex G. Malloy (American Games, 1999) at p. 34, #1033.

Legenden des Schwertes ("Legends of the Sword") is a strategy board game for 2-4 players at the age of 12+.

Each player takes control of a samurai family that competes for the title of the new Shogun. Players must manage their province, villages and build castles, recruit units and complete missions.

The game is aimed at all strategy fans who love the setting up and managing of a little kingdom. The uniqueness of the game is that the players are able to gain victory over a lot of different strategies and every match is unique. There will never be a game that is similar to a previous one! In addition, the game offers an exciting battle system in which players must tactically operate and not just roll dice.

Game description:

Legenden des Schwertes is a round based strategy game. At the start of the game, every player gets a set of mission cards and event cards. The mission cards are required to get victory points. The event cards can be used to manipulate combat between armies. The game is played in clockwise direction and every player has one turn per round.

The player's turn consists of five steps:
1. Receive income
2. Built and convert buildings
3. Hire units
4. Move and fight with your armies
5. End your turn and get victory points for completed missions cards

The game ends if a player has twelve or more victory points.

May the greatest strategic genius win!

R-R-R-R-Race toward the finish line at ludicrous speed! In Turbo Drift , you must make your way through an analog racecourse full of obstacles by drafting movement cards from columns or rows or even pushing-your-luck and try to use all the movement cards. Turbo Drift will make a big presence on your gaming table with obstacle cards and nitro-infused gameplay, yet small enough to put in your pocket for some lunchtime gaming.

Turbo Drift is a real-space racing game for 2-4 players that takes 30 minutes to play. Players will take turns picking 1,2,or 3 path cards from a grid to navigate their cars closer to the goal card. Once per game, they can go turbo, using all of the cards in the grid to drive. The first player to cross the finish line wins!

name.value: We Were Not Cowards: Sedan 1870 & The Fall of the Second Empire

item.description:
We Were Not Cowards: Sedan 1870 & The Fall of the Second Empire is a grand tactical scale wargame by Ray Weiss covering the final desperate battle for Sedan in what amounted to Napoleon the III's last day in power.

The game uses Kevin Zucker's The Library of Napoleonic Battles series rules as a base and builds upon those to simulate the intricacies of military operations representing all levels of command and control. Units are at a brigade, division, squadron, or battery scale, with 1000 men per infantry Strength Point. Turns are approximately 1 hour each.

The game not only covers the somewhat hopeless historical battle, but also explores several "What if?" scenarios that explore what may have happened had Durcot retained command after MacMahon was wounded from Wimpiffen and ordered a retreat towards Paris. There are 2 other "What If?" scenarios that allow the french to respond to the Prussian encirclement which occurred a day before the actual battle.

What Just Happened is a competitive/cooperative storytelling game, similar to Cards Against Humanity, for 3-6 players that takes 30-45 minutes to play. Each player picks a character, plays an item on a character, and then tells the story that they feel transpired using the cards in play. The catch? You only have 60 seconds.

Each card has a points value that is based on how difficult the card is to use in a story with a little bias towards cards children can use. As each card is used, you "turn" it to denote that you have used that card in your story. At the end of your story you add up all the cards that you used correctly. The person with the most points each round wins the round. After you win 3 rounds you win the game!

name.value: Sky Kingdoms: Good Evil & Primal Forces

item.description:
Establish dominance of the skies with armies of battle-hardened warriors who attack from ancient machinations of war called Sky Kingdoms. Take control of the Good, Evil or Primal forces in this fast paced, expandable card game. Decimate opposing forces, and lay waste to their floating realms, then claim enough gold to build a new flying fortress capable of not only winning the battle, but the war itself.

At a glance
Sky Kingdoms is a light strategy game intended to keep every player engaged and active at every point of the game. The round-robin game mechanic (think Poker) keeps turns fast, and a single stat (think Blizzard's Hearthstone) makes for simple yet strategic gameplay.

Object of the Game
The goal of Sky Kingdoms is to collect as much Gold as possible by battling for control of the Skies. The first player to collect enough gold wins the game.

Card Battle mechanic
Each turn is made up of a series of Combat Rounds, where each player has the opportunity to use over 48 unique Unit Cards and Battle Cards in combination to produce the highest Combat Value, win Combat and collect Gold.

item.description:
This is a simple roll and move game. The players start at space 1 and advance according to the die roll. The first player to reach space 60 wins the game. Every few spaces depict another olympic sports competition. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The game includes two dice, but the rules don't mention how many dice are actually used. So it probably depends if one wants to play a short or a long game.

The game was probably published 1924 or 1928.

Eduskuntapeli is roll and move game from the sixties, where your want your party members to be elected to Finnish parliament (Eduskunta).

On your turn you roll the die and move one of your party members in the game board. Some areas in the game board are electoral districts, where you collect random amount of votes (1000-4000). 10000 votes gets you candidate to be elected to parliament. When you have gathered at least 10000 votes for your current candidate, you can move him/her to parliament. Then you can start moving and collecting votes for your next party member. Every player has 16 candidates.

Of course there are some squares where you have to pick up a random event card. Event cards might give you votes or get your party member to be elected as a minister or get the whole government to be moved to some parliamentary committee.

Other way to get your party member to government is to move one of your already elected members of parliament to government squares on the board. You want you MP's into government because then you get extra votes.
 Game ends when one player gets all his/her party members elected to parliament. Winner is the player with most votes, when the game ends.

7 Seize is a speedy battle of pirate wits that anyone can play with common bits & bobs found around the home along with a standard deck of cards. The Kickstarter includes deck up playing cards with custom art, 49 pieces of booty, and a box that transforms into a balance scale.

Players have 7 rounds to collect as much booty as they can. At the end of the game they weigh their pieces and the heaviest collection wins!

In each round starts with players wagering for the powerful role of Captain. Then the Captain divides some booty into 2 piles. Finally, players play another card to try to seize the best booty. They take turns grabbing pieces in order of rank from Ace to 2.

Infinities: Defiance of Fate is a 4x-lite adventure game based in a cross-over setting of fantasy and science-fiction worlds connected by multiversal rifts. As these rifts open, factions from each world collide as their realities blend into one another. However, the cross-over doesn't end with the story. The game boasts a hybrid gameplay style, blending strategy card game and tactical 4x mechanics with narrative elements. A leader acts as your avatar in the game’s worlds. Leaders are represented as a board with a set of actions, three attribute tracks, and a reaction track which holds resource tokens. The basic round structure begins with all players setting one action die matching their map tile, rolling 3 more dice (with an optional reroll), then spending dice to take actions one player at a time. Action dice allow you to play unit and action cards, attack enemies, and explore and control map tiles. Units and leaders add new twists with their own unique actions while in play. At the end of the round, all leaders reset their hands with new cards, a Rift tile morphs the worlds it is connecting, then players check for objectives and Influence.

Infinities offers two primary game modes: Story and Skirmish. In Story mode, two factions use a Story Guide to follow a branching narrative campaign with varied, asymmetric actions, objectives, and win conditions. Based on the events and outcomes within a chapter, players will proceed to one of many possible chapters and make a thematic change to the game's assets for the remainder of the campaign. These changes range from removing leaders, shuffling cards into other decks, or permanently increasing action dice. Additionally, each chapter may change allegiances, leading players through free-for-all, team, one vs. all, and cooperative engagements. This makes it quite likely that players will experience both sides of the story throughout a campaign. Also included in the Story Guide are solo quests for each of the game's leaders, offering scalable challenges with multiple endings.

In Skirmish mode, players strive to collect more points than their opponents from a set of objectives. Skirmish mode functions as an ideal way to learn, practice, and master the game in friendly or competitive matches.

With shared or separate decks, dice-based actions, shifting turn order, a player-created game map, optional unlockable powers, a myriad of dynamic victory conditions, and session-specific actions, you’ll find that the possibilities in this game are infinite.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The tourist season is fast approaching. As a mansion owner, you've come to the Freak Shop to stock your mansion with the horrors that will guarantee that your visitors have a most unforgettable stay!

Freak Shop is a short and simple tactical card game for 2 to 5 players that relies on a tricky trade mechanism. All cards in the game represent the frightening things, with values going from 1 to 10, that any real good freaky mansion owner must have in their collection. Players begin with four cards in their mansion (personal area), and cards are available in the Freak Shop (common zone at the center of the table). Each player's aim is to have their mansion worth the most fear points when the Freak Shop closes, with points coming from a combination of three randomly chosen objectives. To achieve this, they try to make the best trades between cards currently in their mansion and cards available in the Shop so that their collection grows in both quantity and value, while also best fitting the objectives.

On your turn, you make one single trade between cards currently in your mansion and cards available in the Shop. To do that, you have the choice between two options:


 Sell at the fair price => Trade any number of cards totaling a given value for any number of cards worth exactly the same total value. 
 Get a good deal => Exchange a series of cards of one single value with a series of the same number of cards of another single value.


Throughout a game of Freak Shop, you try to take the best trade opportunities each turn to first make your mansion grow, then ensure that you can end with the collection worth the most points. Good deals help to get higher value cards, and fair price trades help to get more cards in your mansion. As everything is about trades, a central strategic point is to determine which cards are better used for optimizing new trades instead of being kept for scoring!

name.value: Marvel Universe Miniature Game: Superior Spiderman Starter Set

item.description:
The Spider-Man Miniature Game is an expansion annexed to the BMG rules based on your favorite Web-slinger!
With this rules you will be able to build a crew with the most famous heroes and the worst maniacs from New York City!
In addition to the new releases, old heroes and villains will join the ranks of the new crews and gangs!

A copy of the Batman Miniature Game rulebook is needed to play.

Just when things started to go good for Peter Parker (for once), something bad happened. While visiting a dying Otto Octavius, Peter suddenly had his mind swapped with Otto's, allowing Otto to live and run around in Peter's body. But just before Peter died, Otto discovered the "true" meaning of "With great power comes great responsibility" via Peter's harrowing memories, so he decided to live up to Peter's legacy and become the Superior Spider-Man.

name.value: Marvel Universe Miniature Game: Goblin Cult Starter Set

item.description:
The Spider-Man Miniature Game is an expansion annexed to the BMG rules based on your favorite Web-slinger!
With this rules you will be able to build a crew with the most famous heroes and the worst maniacs from New York City!
In addition to the new releases, old heroes and villains will join the ranks of the new crews and gangs!

A copy of the Batman Miniature Game rulebook is needed to play.

The Green Goblin Cult, a group of individuals who secretly 'worshipped' Norman Osborn and his worldview. This cult would play heavily in getting Norman removed from incarceration and they should not be confused with Norman's other cult-following, the Order of the Goblin.

Great Comics Adventure is a tabletop card game celebrating the history of Comic Book Characters from the Golden Age. The deck includes 90 Triumph Cards and 18 City Cards. Several major cities are represented in 'The Great Comic Adventure' (GCA) all featured as post-cards. On the back of each post-card is the sequence of cards required to 'claim' that city. Once the five cards in your hands match the post-card, it is then claimed. Once you claim a city you will grab another, and once you claim three cities you win the round!

All the characters and images used in this game are from the Public Domain, so they belong to all of us! In general, works published after 1977 will not fall into the public domain until 70 years after the death of author, or, for corporate works, anonymous works, or works for hire, 95 years from the date of publication or 120 years from the date of creation, whichever expires first. Pre-1978 works what are in the public domain because they were published without proper copyright notice, or, in the case of pre-1964 works, were not timely renewed, do not receive retroactive protection under the CTEA. Similarly, works published before 1923, do not receive retroactive protection, and remain in the public domain. All of these comic books were published in the Golden Age of Comic Book History which all started with one super hero, Superman. The Golden Age could be given a specific start time thank to Superman #14 (Feb. 1942), this is when we ushered in the Golden Age of Comic Books. The Golden Age of Comic Books describes an era of American comic books from the late 1930s to the early 1950s. During this time, modern comic books were first published and rapidly increased in popularity. All the comics in the game feature comics from the 1940's and 1950's along with the post card designs featured as well.

Hästspelet is action-packed, eventful, fun and exciting game for everyone.

Hästspelet is a board game where you compete against each other to become the first to achieve three milestones. 
These three milestones are: building up the horse farm, win races and to collect a certain amount of money.

The game can be played at three levels: local, regional or national.
The levels affect the playtime and requirements of the milestones.

Some of the things that can happen during the game, competing in dressage, jumping and trot, chasing money, questions and fun and less fun "Mockor"
Mockor are random events that can affect both you and others of good and evil.

The questions for the game are mixed in different categories and divided into three age groups: children, youth and adults. 
This means that you will compete on the same terms.
The questions and "Mockor" are on an APP that is available for free download for both Android and Apple.
The APP requires no internet connection after installation.

You don’t have be a horse person to play this Hästspelet, likewise to you don’t have to be a broker to play monopoly.

Preparations
It requires the free app Hästspelet downloaded to a phone or tablet.
The app contains the questions and mockor needed to play. The download and installation takes a few minutes. The app requires no internet connection after installation. In the meantime you can prepare the bank with banknotes and read the rules. Unfold and place the game board so that everyone reaches it. Before the game begins, all players must agree on what level they will select.

The start
Start by placing the buildings "house and stables" in all the blank squares on the game board. This area represents each player's horse farm. Then distribute the SEK 50 000, a horse farm card, a holder for the game piece and a horse for all participants. The horse should be the same color as the two boxes labeled "Inackordering" on the board.
All then select the respective game character piece, attach it to its holder that has the same color as the horse. Place the game character piece in the starting box. Let a roll of the dice to decide who starts playing.
Always roll two dice during the game (with the exception of mockorna). The order is always clockwise. The bank pays out 30 000 SEK each time a player passes the starting box.

The milestones
Milestone 1 - Build a horse farm
Horse farm built by landing on the "Mäklare” (Broker) ", where the player can buy buildings to their horse farm. You can buy several buildings at the same time. Read on horse farm card for more information.

Milestone 2 - Gain Diploma
Diplomas obtained by winning races. The Bank manages the distribution of the award to the winner of a contest, with the prize money standing on diploma card.
The winner and runner-up parts of the money in the pot. If the pot is uneven it is awarded to the winner advantage.

Milestone 3 - Cash
Cash acquire it through: to win races, coming second in the competitions, the boarders at your horse farm, answering the question right, pass the Start box, some mockor and on the horse market where you can sell.

There are special Contest Rules for "jumping", "Dressage" and "racetrack" because it is a competitive element of the game that often occur. Much because of the desire to win money, which in turn generates that one can buy buildings to their horse farm. Last but not least, you will gain a diploma when you win.

There are rules for three and two players and rules for five and four players that is slightly different from when there is 6 players.

What makes this game a little unique is precisely the balance of the questions and mockorna, racing adrenaline and the crazy events that may occur in mockorna. And also fun with an APP for a board game, it makes it feel new and fresh.

Welcome to the Orctoberfest, where all creatures of the fantasy world are invited to have a beer and a sausage before the next bumpy rollercoaster ride. This yearly fair is pretty crowded, though, and long queues await the visitors before they are able to quench their thirst.

In the role-selection game Orctoberfest, the players try to satisfy their characters by reducing their waiting time in the queues for bratwurst, beer and pretzels. The sooner a character gets served, the happier he is, leaving the queue for the beer hall. The player with the most happiness at the end of the game wins — but not everybody plays fair and wants to wait for their turn, trying to jump the queue, or worse, using their body odor to scare others out of the waiting line.

Different character abilities provide interesting decisions for the players throughout the game. Playing the right character at the right time, assessing the situation on the table correctly, and predicting the plays of your opponents are the keys to victory in this fast-playing queue-building game.

item.description:
A 2-player abstract game, designed by C. W. Cowsley and distributed by Applied Technology in 1989. The game consists of twelve top-hat shaped tokens (10 yellow numbered from 1-10, 1 red and 1 blue), the instructions, and a green cloth bag which doubles up as a double-sided game board.

One player plays as Red, the other as Blue. The object of the game is to capture the highest total of numbered yellow tokens, without your own token being captured by your opponent. The tokens are designed so that they can be easily pressed together, so that the players' red and blue tokens gradually accumulate a stack of yellow tokens underneath them as the game progresses.

The board consists of ten circles, connected by lines in a geometric pattern. There are two variant configurations, one printed on each side of the cloth bag. The game is played in two phases: firstly, each player alternately places one numbered token on a circle until all ten have been placed; secondly players take turns moving their red or blue token along the lines from circle to circle, capturing tokens as they move, until either all ten numbered tokens have been captured - or one player has blundered allowing their own token to be captured! The advantage of going first is mitigated by placing an upper limit on the first token that the starting player may capture - in the basic game, this is fixed at 6; in the advanced game this is decided by auction.

Welcome to the Artworld: The Card Game! Artworld is playable as art critic who rates art, and art collectors who buy art through auction and sell the art to the critic for money and points. To win, the art collectors must excel in reading the critic's taste and predicting what kind of art the critic would like, and what kind of art the critic would dislike. It is also possible for art collectors to make a set of artworks (3, 5 or 7 cards) that have same traits, in order to get points. First collector who reaches 10 million dollars or 5 points wins the game.

name.value: Baptism By Fire: The Battle of Kasserine

item.description:
Baptism By Fire: The Battle of Kasserine, February 1943 chronicles the first real ground operations by the US Army in the ETO in WW2. Every wargamer knows this battle was a severe Allied setback. What is not obvious, however, is that Allied troops on the ground gave a good account of themselves against the remnants of Rommel's vaunted Afrika Korps, despite the ineffective and confused leadership that existed at Corps level.

In the end, while GIs and Tommies fought their guts out to make up for the mistakes of their leadership, the advantages achieved by initial Axis successes were allowed to blow away in the wind by an equally detached and confused Axis High Command. In its case, how to best exploit the results of their initial attack depended on an argument raging within the Italian Commando Supremo and the persuasive abilities of Albert Kesselring and Erwin Rommel. After much discussion and the loss of several crucial days, the Axis decided on the less ambitious plan, which was itself no longer even possible.

Baptism By Fire is the second game in the Battalion Combat Series (BCS), which took players by storm with its block buster initial release Last Blitzkrieg. The game is designed as a more accessible entry to the system for those who want something smaller and faster than the earlier monster game. Here the wide open desert, limited number of Formations, and short scenario length provide players with a rapid and fun introduction to the series, the chance to develop their play skills to become a more effective BCS player overall, and to take a good look at this poorly understood battle.

Once again, the masterful order of battle research by Carl Fung showcases the forces involved with more fine detail than ever before. As a result, the common misconceptions of hapless GIs and Afrika Korps supermen is put to rest.

To give players a better feel for the pulse of the battle, the Germans run rampant for a few turns but then must idle back for several more while their commanders figure out what the overall objective will be. The player selects this objective randomly in the middle of the game, and it determines his Victory Conditions. This precludes the Axis player from overusing his limited combat power beforehand (since he might be going down the wrong road, literally) and keeps the Allies off balance as they must protect against both possibilities.

With a campaign game of only 10 turns, multiple plays are readily possible and various strategies for both sides can be explored.

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 day
Hex: 1 mile
Units: Battalion (w/a few Companies)

Scenarios:
Kasserine Campaign, 2 maps, 10 Turns
Operation Spring Wind, 1 map, 4 Turns
Mid-Campaign Start, 2 maps, 5 Turns
Between a Rock and a Hard Place, 1 map, 5 Turns
End Campaign Start, 2 maps, 3 Turns
High Water Mark, 1 map, 3 Turns
Components:

BCS rulebook (version 1.1, in full color)
Two BCS Charts and Tables
BCS Crib Notes Booklet
BBF Game Specific rulebook
Two 22” x34” Full Color Game Maps
560 Counters (one sheet of units and one BCS marker sheet)
6 scenarios total, 3 one-map scenarios
Box and Dice

Holland '44, Operation Market-Garden, September 1944 is a two-player game depicting the Allies’ combined ground and airborne attack in the Netherlands during WWII, which was code named Operation Market-Garden.

The game starts with the airborne landings on September 17th and continues until September 23rd. The Allied player must rush his ground forces forward as fast as possible to relieve his beleaguered airborne divisions and capture a bridge across the Rhine.

The scale of the map is 2 kilometers per hex and covers the battlefield from the Belgian border to Arnhem. The map also includes the area where the British 8th Corps fought on the right flank of 30th Corps.

Most units in Holland ‘44 are battalions, but units range from Company to Brigades.

Holland '44 uses a system very similar to Ardennes '44. It is basically a simple move-fight, I-go then u-go game. If you have played Ardennes '44 or Normandy '44 you will have no trouble learning the game. Rules such as ZOC Bonds, Determined Defense, Extended Movement, and Traffic Markers all make their reappearance. Due to the terrain of the Netherlands, special attention was given to river crossings, bridge building, and fighting in the flat polder terrain.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 3 turns per day (AM, PM & Night)
Hex: 1.24 miles / 2 kilometers
Units: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full color map
One 17 x 22" full color map (together = 22 x 43.5")
Two dual-side printed countersheet (468 9/16" counters)
One 40-page Holland '44 rulebook
Two dual-side printed Player Aid cards
One single-side printed Setup Card
Two 6-sided dice

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium-High
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-15 hours

item.description:
You are taking a trip to Venice, where the famous carnival is held.
While walking around, a masked lady challenges you to a gem hunt in the middle of a canal.
Use the planks to go from pile to pile to find your way through this labyrinth!

Each player picks a colour and has to collect four gems: rubies for the red player, diamonds for the white player, emeralds for the green player and topazes for the yellow player. Use your stock of planks to go from one pile to another.
A player wins the game if he/she is the first to collect all 4 gems of his/her colour.

The game can then continue to determine who comes second, third and fourth.

item.description:
In Hand of Manus players take roles of craftsman guild leaders, competing to construct and present the best hand for valorous warrior Manus, who lost his hand in a battle.
Each round players design and then test their constructs in a test room. A hand consists of three parts - shoulder, forearm and wrist and each part has affinity to different elements, so it's performance depends on testing conditions. Every round players bet on expected performance for their hand and then secretly influence testing conditions. Whoever fulfills their bet scores points accordingly, and a first player to get 12 points wins.

item.description:
AbrakaRun is a game in which we will play the role of a wizard. He will have to move on a board to get first to the finish line, the King's Castle.
We will cast spells (yes, you are right in reading "spells") in order to move around the board because we want to become the greatest wizard of this Kingdom.
We will have "hidden" tokens to cast a spell and it will require a good memory on our part to use them. These important magic words are needed not only to get ahead, but also to fight the other wizards whose aim is to reach the goal too.

Description in Spanish:
ABRAKARUN, un juego donde interpretaremos el papel de un mago que deberá avanzar por un tablero para conseguir llegar el primero a la meta, el castillo del Rey.

Para avanzar, usaremos hechizos (sí, has leído bien, hechizos) porque queremos ser el mayor mago del reino. Para invocar esos hechizos necesitaremos ingredientes, que encontraremos en forma de tokens ocultos por lo que necesitaremos una buena memoria para poder utilizar los hechizos.

Estos hechizos no sólo nos permitirán avanzar, sino que también podremos atacar al resto de magos que intentan llegar al castillo y perjudicarles en su loca carrera hacia la meta.

Explore Alexander's decisive battle in a card-based system designed by Richard Berg. This is not a "card-driven" game, nor one with a traditional mapboard, but one in which the units and leaders themselves are cards that capture the abilities and appearance of the two armies. Cards face, move, and fight within their own grid. Game options include a "historical" battle deployment or allowing you to "do better" on your own.

name.value: Band of Brothers: Old Breed South Pacific

item.description:
Band of Brothers: Old Breed South Pacific is a fast playing game of squad level combat in WWII. It covers the exploits of the U.S. First Marine Division in the battles for Guadalcanal. The rules are very simple (no combat charts are needed) with very few exceptions to remember and yet the game is meant to be all encompassing and will include infantry, tanks, and artillery.

Based on years of research, the game system uses a unique suppression mechanic. There are no longer two unique states for a unit, but varying degrees of suppression. This allows suppression to accumulate from multiple fire sources and means that the unit will not take a morale check until it is asked to do something. You will never know for sure how your units will respond until they are needed.

Although casualties can be caused by artillery and heavy weapons (which makes them prime battlefield targets), squads will never cause significant casualties shooting at range at dug in, first line troops. Their goal is to fire and maneuver. Sections of the enemy force must be pinned down and eliminated from up close. The system itself forces this realistic play. In a similar fashion, the system rewards you for spreading your troops out and other realistic game play.

Another unique feature of the game is its use of Proficiency and Casualty ratings to differentiate squads in areas besides just morale.

Old Breed South Pacific is a STAND ALONE GAME, but is also part of a growing series of tactical games.

Band of Brothers: Screaming Eagles is the first in the series and follows the U.S. 101st Airborne Division.

Band of Brothers: Ghost Panzer is the second in the series and follows the German 11th Panzer Division.

Band of Brothers: Texas Arrows is a dependant expansion that follows the U.S. 36th Infantry Division.

2-3 player strategy game with a 2 team 4 player cooperative variant. Set in Ancient Greece, players try to reach the Golden Fleece and bring it to any of the 4 cities at the corners of the board. Opponents try to trap or land on the player with the Golden Fleece. Trapped players are teleported to the corner squares minus the Fleece. The winner is the first player to get the Fleece to a corner square / city.

In GoodWill, you play an investor, trying to maximize his capital by buying and selling the shares of 3 companies, thanks to the privileged information you have access to.

Each turn, each investor has a look at two end-of-turn events, changing prices resources, rationalizing production chain of a firm or advertising occurring that help a firm gain market shares...
Based on this information, players will estimate a price for each firm. Players who gave lowest price will send a share to the one who gave the highest price.

name.value: The New Game of Divers or Hidden Treasure

item.description:
This game from Parker Brothers takes a concept used by early fishing games and re-themes it to divers trying to hook sunken treasure.

The game includes a fold-out cardboard "tank" about 9" square and 6.5" high. Each wall contains a mesh-covered arch through which players can see to some extent what they are doing. There are two foot-long wooden poles, each with a string dangling from one end leading to a 2.5"-tall deep-sea diver figure with a small metal hook at its feet. The treasure consists of small cardboard rectangles, each with a metal loop projecting from the back, and the type of treasure (gold, silver, jewels) printed on the bottom with a value.

The treasures are placed value down at the bottom of the tank, and players must dangle their divers over the wall, twisting the rods to try and hook the treasures. The game can be played as a race between two people that lasts until all the treasure has been retrieved. Or it can be played by more people, with each player getting three minutes to hook as much as possible. Either way, the largest value of treasure (not number of catches) wins the game.

This is a fantasy-themed roll-and-move game with a three-dimensional board. The board comes in three segments: two of these form a colorful truncated pyramid when pegged together, and the third forms a square ivy-covered stone tower that fits into the top of the pyramid.

Each side of the pyramid has 35 holes for pegs on a winding path up to the tower; each side of the tower has a further 11 holes leading to the window where the princess presumably awaits rescue.

Each player rolls a die to climb one side of the pyramid and then up the adjacent wall. There are no shortcuts up, but eight spaces have slides back down. First player to rescue the princess wins. The rules suggest a party variation, in which four "prizes" are placed in the tower, and players get to choose a prize in order of finish.

The box is not dated, but the game is listed in the 1946 Catalog of Copyright Entries.

This is a game of global travel and trade. It consists of six miniature ships, two different spinners, and a four-section map of the world measuring roughly 35" x 20". The map bears a variety of different routes available (Panama vs. Cape Horn, Suez vs. Cape of Good Hope, etc.) that can be sailed in either direction.

The objective is to complete a trip around the world while picking up the greatest value of cargo. Players each start with a ship in New York and spin for their initial cargo. They then announce a direction and destination, and when they arrive at that port, can add a cargo based on the chief exports of that port as listed on the board.

When leaving a port, players who spin greater than 3 move quickly but face a financial penalty (for being delayed in port). The winner is not the player who completes the round the world voyage first, but whoever finishes with the highest total value of cargo. If a ship is destroyed by landing on a storm, all cargo is lost, the player gets a spin for insurance to offset the lost, but starts again from New York.

Brutal close-quarters combat in the 41st Millennium

The Game

No strength in numbers. No margin for error. Pure, fast-paced combat where tactics matter more than brute strength, and every action matters. A single shot can spell the difference between life and death, and a single decision can decide whether a battle ends in glorious victory or dismal defeat: this is Warhammer 40,000: Kill Team.

A whole new way to play games with your Warhammer 40,000 miniatures, this standalone two-player game puts you in charge of small bands of warriors, and gives you one objective – win, or die.

item.description:
For generations, witch doctors have tried to make a resurrection potion. Attempting a variety of herbs, insects, minerals and liquids to construct a potion to vitalize life. The result was called “NECTAR” .

The “NECTAR” refers to a hand card and element collection game allowing 2-4 players to play at the same time.

In the game, players play as witch doctors to construct a formula by utilizing all available resources to develop a potion in the sacrificial stage. The players who can formulate the most highly purified potion will win the game.

This is an unprecedented world of wonders, in which imagination and wisdom will become your catalyst.

The best part of the game is that you can mix different tools and materials from the fantasy world to produce unexpected results.

If you love imagining the world and would like to escape from the dull real life for a little while, or just want to have some fun with your family, friends and neighbors, the “NECTAR” is the best choice for you.

The fire is rising, while the witch doctor is formulating the valuable “NECTAR”.

At the start of the game, each player draws 6 cards. Players will place one card each from the deck into the sacrificial pot. Players then take turns, placing one to two cards from their hand on the board. When all the cards between two sacrificial pots satisfy the necessary condition, the collection of cards will be put into the discard pile and the player will gain one point. These conditions include:

1. A total of five basic kind of medical ingredients: toads, snails, spiders, mushrooms, and skulls.
2. Gather four of the same basic medical ingredients
3. Potency level or 11 or above

If the results conform to several scoring rules at the same time, an extra point will be awarded. Players can also use token and prop cards to change the situation in the game.

This is a quiz game regarding the Greek cinema. With this game you share beautiful moments with your friends by putting in test your memory and knowledge about famous greek old and modern movies. The game components: Board, 6 pawns, 484 cards, a die and the rules

The objective of The County Fair Game is to have the most fun at the county fair by spending as much of your money to win prizes, be awarded ribbons, take photos, eat food and experience the fair. Players begin with 85 play dollars to spend at the fair. Before entering the fair, they must first find a parking place (roll to land in spaces around the outer edge of the board.) Upon entering the fair, players roll a die each turn and can choose which space to land on (usually from several options.) The player with the most points from accumulated prizes, and experiences wins.

name.value: Das kleine Gespenst: Spuk auf Burg Eulenstein

item.description: Every night in Das kleine Gespenst: Spuk auf Burg Eulenstein, the little ghost awakes at the witching hour to run through the castle rooms to play. Its favorite game is cannonball bowling — but where did it hide the cannonballs last time? Who can help the little ghosts find them again? Who has been paying attention to which chests hide which cannonballs?

name.value: Mille Bornes: Edition spéciale Sécurité Routière

item.description:
Small version of the old french classic game given for free during 2016 summer holidays on french highways. This was for educate drivers on road safety.

Only 32 cards in this version:
16 mileage cards 
4 dump hazard cards (1 classic - red light - and 3 specifics for this version: Alcohol, Phone call, no motorcycle equipment)
8 remedy hazard cards (green light, negative ethylotest, end the call, motorcycle equipment)
4 safety cards (emergency vehicle, SAM - the guy who drives don't drink, hands free kit, full equipment and airbag

Other changes from the usual rules of the game:
The goal is to reach 500 km
No need of a green light at first before playing mileage cards

A deplorable tabletop game devoid of joy, hope, or humor; which, regrettably, is also far more awesome than it has any right to be.

In Endangered Orphans of Condyle Cove, players take turns choosing to move around the board, playing options to either help their orphan survive, or make their opponent's orphan suffer.

When an orphan either runs out of options, or in an act of desperation, reveals the boogeyman, the boogeyman takes the orphan.

When all but one orphan are taken by the boogeyman, the game ends, and the last orphan to survive is the winner.

The Endangered Orphans set includes:


 Condyle Cove Core Game
 Boogeyman Solo Play Figure
 Fourth Player Expansion
 Last Winter Expansion
 The Ghost of Benny Harris Expansion

item.description:
Ambition and a thirst for wealth have driven humanity to strive for ever greater progress. In America, during the 19th century, battles were waged between huge railway corporations that sought to connect state to state and coast with coast… making themselves filthy rich in the process. Railroad Revolution drops you straight into the middle of these tempestuous years; a time that changed America forever.

In Railroad Revolution, you will manage your own railroad company, ruthlessly competing to be the most powerful railroad tycoon across all America. You will build railroads, establish stations in your connected cities, expand the network of telegraph lines, and chase your objectives, increasing the value of your company with every action you take.

You start with mainly a team of non-specialized workers, but during the game you can hire additional ones with specific skill sets. The cost or effect of an action is determined by the type of worker that does it. To complete your company objectives, you will have to remove some of your workers from your active pool, promoting them to managerial positions. You must carefully assign each of your workers to perform the right action at the right time in order to exploit their specializations in the best way. You need to decide which ones to promote and which are instead still needed to take actions, as your priorities will change from turn to turn.

Railroad Revolution is a fast paced game with relatively simple rules, and it provides you with interesting and challenging decisions. Having a good strategy and finding the correct timing to implement it, is the key to winning the game.

item.description: Imagine a 10-day trip through Switzerland. During your journey you visit the cantons and lakes that have a common border. You eventually will have to ride a train, bus or a seaplane to connect two destinations. With a little luck, you will draw a card that is perfect for your trip. In the end, 10 regions and means of transport must be aligned in the right order, Simple rules that guarantee fun and entertainment for children and adults.

name.value: The Lords of Rock: Mosh Pit

item.description:
A 10 card micro game tied to the "Lords of Rock" card game universe.

This micro game is a challenge between you and the other players to try to get your player Pantheon card into the front and center section of the mosh pit before the concert starts. Flipping and moving card will cause the seating to re-arrange itself and you have to be good enough to try to make sure your card ends up front and center for the concert.

This is a stand alone micro game.

item.description: The goal is to be the first player to reach the top of his mountain. To do so, each player draw a tile picturing something. If the first letter of the image is on your mountain, you "climbed" it.

Come in our fun fair and relive the feeling of the penny-fall game!
Play your chips on the board, push , and... shall fall or not?...
Win points but careful not to be too greedy at the risk of having no more chips to play your turn!
Here we go!
